root.geography: Spoken in the Caucasus Mountain region of the USSR between Black Sea and the Caspian Sea. “Virtually all the North Caucasian languages are... spoken on the northern slopes of the Great Caucasus range, except for Abkhaz, spoken on the Black sea coast in the Abkhaz Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic, a province of the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic” (Catford 1991:239).

child.geography: Spoken in the southern Dagestan and northern Azerbaijan.

child.pub-comments: Although the author includes Khinalug into the Peripheral group of the Lezgian languages (Catford 1991:234), in the “family tree” of Caucasian languages Khinalug shows a closer relationship to the Nakh Degestanian subgroup (Catford 1991:236).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.geography: Spoken in two villages in northern Azerbijan and one village in eastern Georgia.
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: “Among Lezgian languages, Archi, spoken in an isolated position, flanked by Avar and Lak, is something of an outlier, as is Udi, spoken in two villages in northern Azerbijan and one village in eastern Georgia” (Catford 1991:237).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: Editor's comment: the Peripheral group includes Lezgian languages that do not belong to the Samurian or Shah Dagh subgroups. Though the author includes Khinalug into the Peripheral group, in the “family tree” figure of Caucasian languages the author shows Khinalung's closer relationship directly to Nakho-Dagestanian rather than to the Lezgian subgroup (Catford 1991:236).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.geography: Spoken largely along the course of the Samur river, chiefly in Dagestan but with some slight spillover into Azerbaijan.

child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: “The most compact group of Lezgian languages is spoken largely along the course of the Samur river (hence “Samur languages”), chiefly in Dagestan but with some slight spillover into Azerbaijan” (Catford 1991:237).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.geography: Spoken in northern Azerbaijan near the mountain Shah Dagh.

child.geography: Spoken in the Dagestan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic (ASSR), chiefly in the extremely mountainous southern and western part of the ASSR.
Spoken in the western salient of Dagestan, where pockets of Avar are also found and where Avar is the lingua franca of the area.

child.pub-comments: Literary language. Number of speakers: half a million. The self-name of the Avar language is maʕarul mat̄s̄ˈ or 'mountain language' (Catford 1991:240).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: The Nakho-Dagestanian group “consists of two distinct subdivisions, namely, the small close-knit Nakh group and the much larger and more diverse Dagestanian group” (Catford 1991:237).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.geography: Spoken in Adygei Autonomous Oblast' (AO) and in a few scattered locations nearer the Black Sea coast.
child.pub-comments: Literary language.
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.geography: Chiefly spoken in the Kabardino-Balkar Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic and also in Karachay-Cherkess Autonomous Oblast' (AO).
child.pub-comments: Literary language. “...The Kabardian speakers are known as “Cherkess”, hence the official Russian name of the language kabardino-čerkesskij jazyk” (Catford 1991:239).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: Catford marks some nodes, as this one, by numbers “that represent lexico-statistical percentages, based on the Swadesh 100-word list on the Swadesh 100-word list... these are to be regarded as quite tentative, but they provide some quantitative support to the accepted groupings” (Catford 1991:235). This node is marked by 90% of shared vocabulary (Catford 1991:236). “When the great Circassian Diaspora occurred, the Adygan languages were unwritten, and so the dispersed Circassians of the Middle East were largely illiterate in their own language, except for some ingenious local attempts at devising an orthography. One of the most interesting of these was the Roman orthography devised in Damascus by a Circassian (Bzhedugh) schoolmaster... in the 1930s, an orthography that had a certain local currency certainly into the 1940s. More recently, members of the Circassian community (nearly 3,000) in Israel petitioned the Israeli Ministry of Education to have their children introduced to reading and writing in Adyge” (Catford 1991:240).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: Number of speakers: one speaker. Ubykh is a language isolate, which the author “somewhat arbitrarily indicated in the tree diagram as closer to Adygan than to Abkhazan. In point of fact, Ubykh is lexicostatistically about equally related to both (about 36% to 40% shared cognates). Phonologically closer to Abkhazan, but grammatically probably closer to Adygan” (Catford 1991:237). Ubykh “is no longer spoken in the Caucasus because all its speakers left in the 1860s. […] the last fully competent speaker of Ubykh, Tevfik Esenc... is alive and well and living near Manyas, in Anatolia, just south of the Sea of Marmora. Maynas is... the “terminal location” of Ubykh” (Catford 1991:239). “The story behind the removal of Ubykh (and other languages) to Turkey is as follows. About 1864 the Russians invaded and finally conquered Circassia in the northwestern Caucasus. A great number (estimated nearly half a million) of Northwest Caucasian Muslims migrated to Turkey when their homeland was invaded. A great many were settled in Turkey, where their descendants, including the last speaker of Ubykh, still alive” (Catford 1991:239).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: Ubykh is a language isolate, which the author “somewhat arbitrarily indicated in the tree diagram as closer to Adygan than to Abkhazan. In point of fact, Ubykh is lexicostatistically about equally related to both (about 36% to 40% shared cognates). Phonologically closer to Abkhazan, but grammatically probably closer to Adygan” (Catford 1991:237).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.geography: Spoken alongside the Kabardian language in Karachay-Cherkess Autonomous Oblast'.
child.pub-comments: Literary language. “The Caucasian language [Abaza] is spoken in the north, while in the southern part we find a Turkic language, Karachay-Balkar, the two dialects for which are... spoken respectively in the Karachey-Cherkess AO [Autonomous Oblast'] and the Kabardino-Balkar ASSR [Autonomous Soviet Social Republic]” (Catford 1991:239).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.geography: Spoken on the Black sea coast in the Abkhaz Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic, a province of the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic.
child.pub-comments: Literary language.
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: “The Abkhazo-Adygan languages are... spoken in somewhat scattered pockets, though formerly they were widely spread throughout the Northwest Caucasus” (Catford 1991:239). Catford marks some nodes, as this one, by numbers “that represent lexico-statistical percentages, based on the Swadesh 100-word list on the Swadesh 100-word list... these are to be regarded as quite tentative, but they provide some quantitative support to the accepted groupings” (Catford 1991:235). This node is marked by 80% of shared vocabulary (Catford 1991:236).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: Catford marks some nodes, as this one, by numbers “that represent lexico-statistical percentages, based on the Swadesh 100-word list on the Swadesh 100-word list... these are to be regarded as quite tentative, but they provide some quantitative support to the accepted groupings” (Catford 1991:235). This node is marked by 28% of shared vocabulary (Catford 1991:236). “The Abkhazo-Adygan languages very clearly break down into two subgroupings of closely related languages, Abkhazan (Ankhaz and Abaza) and Adygan, also known as Circassian (Adyge, or West Circassian, and Kabardian, or East Circassian). I addition to this groups we have the language isolate, Ubykh, which I have somewhat arbitrarily indicated in the tree diagram as closer to Adygan than to Abkhazan. In point of fact, Ubykh is lexicostatistically about equally related to both (about 36% to 40% shared cognates). Phonologically closer to Abkhazan, but grammatically probably closer to Adygan” (Catford 1991:237).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: “It will be noted that the North Caucasian languages and Kartvelian (South Caucasian) are joint by a dotted line, unlike the full lines joining other groups. This indicates the uncertainty, or improbability, of a genetic relationship between these two branches of Caucasian” (Catford 1991:235). Catford marks some nodes, as this one, by numbers “that represent lexico-statistical percentages, based on the Swadesh 100-word list on the Swadesh 100-word list... these are to be regarded as quite tentative, but they provide some quantitative support to the accepted groupings” (Catford 1991:235). This node is marked by 11% of shared vocabulary (Catford 1991:236).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: “...The only two dialects I have named are... the two dialects of Zan, Megrelian and Laz. The reason is that they are sometimes listed as separate languages in the specialist literature” (Catford 1991:233).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

This node is marked by 44% of shared vocabulary (Catford 1991:236).

child.pub-comments: “South Caucasian is “also known as “Kartvelian,” from Kartveli (pl. Kartvelebi), the self-designation of the Georgians, whose language is called kertuli ena” (Catford 1991:233). “It will be noted that the North Caucasian languages and Kartvelian (South Caucasian) are joined by a dotted line, unlike the full lines joining other groups. This indicates the uncertainty, or improbability, of a genetic relationship between these two branches of Caucasian” (Catford 1991:235). Catford marks some nodes, as this one, by numbers “that represent lexico-statistical percentages, based on the Swadesh 100-word list on the Swadesh 100-word list... these are to be regarded as quite tentative, but they provide some quantitative support to the accepted groupings” (Catford 1991:235). This node is marked by 30% of shared vocabulary (Catford 1991:236).
child.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

root.pub-comments: “By “Caucasian languages” we mean those languages spoken in the Caucasus Mountain region of the USSR between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea that (unlike other languages of the region) are neither Indo-European, Turkic, Mongolic, or Semitic. In Russian they are generally called “Ibero-Caucasian” - iberijskokavkazskie jazyki. The first part of this Russian designation refers to Caucasian Iberia – an ancient Transcaucasian state that from the third century B.C. Was one of the two units composing the kingdom of Georgia, the other being Colchis – not to the Iberian peninsula at the opposite end of Europe. It is true that the term “Ibero-Caucasian” has sometimes been used to refer to a presumed wider grouping of languages [for example, by Holmer 1947] implying a typological or genetic relationship of Caucasian with Basque – a relationship, incidentally, that has long been posited and is currently accepted by some Soviet linguists” (Catford 1991:232). “It will be noted that the North Caucasian languages and Kartvelian (South Caucasian) are joint by a dotted line, unlike the full lines joining other groups. This indicates the uncertainty, or improbability, of a genetic relationship between these two branches of Caucasian” (Catford 1991:235). Catford marks some nodes, as this one, by numbers “that represent lexico-statistical percentages, based on the Swadesh 100-word list on the Swadesh 100-word list... these are to be regarded as quite tentative, but they provide some quantitative support to the accepted groupings” (Catford 1991:235). This node is marked by 6% of shared vocabulary, “specifically shared between Georgian and Abkhazo-Adygan (about 6.3%) and Georgian and Avar (about 5.5%). Some proportion of this, possibly all, is no doubt due to borrowing” (Catford 1991:236). “The number of speakers of these [Caucasian] languages ranges from about 3 million speakers of Georgian, through about half a million speakers of Chechen and Avar, down to only 200 speakers of Gunkukh, and only one speaker of Ubykh” (Catford 1991:233).
root.publications: Catford, J. C. 1991. The Classification of Caucasian Laguages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 232-268. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.
